summary: This document is an email chain between legal counsel in the case of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, discussing procedural matters related to the public filing of reply briefs and exhibits. The correspondence focuses on conferring about proposed redactions to protect the privacy of victims, third parties, and Assistant U.S. Attorneys, as ordered by Judge Nathan. It reveals the negotiation process between the defense and prosecution regarding what information should remain sealed or redacted from the public docket.

persons.name: GMJetter
persons.role: Legal Counsel (sender of email with attachment)
persons.context: Appears to be an attorney involved in the case, sending a letter intended for filing with the court regarding redactions to reply briefs.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: The judge overseeing the US v. Maxwell case, who issued orders (Dkt. 203, 207) directing the parties to address filing and redaction of documents.

events.title: Filing of Letter Regarding Redactions
events.description: An attorney (GMJetter) intends to file a letter on the ECF docket per the court's order (Dkt. 232) to address redactions and sealing of reply briefs and exhibits.

events.title: Submission of Joint Letter
events.description: The parties submitted a joint letter, which Judge Nathan later ordered to be docketed or have redactions proposed by April 19, 2021.

events.title: Court Order on Redactions
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order (Dkt. 168) adopting proposed redactions to certain exhibits (J and O) to protect privacy interests.

keyFacts: The email chain details negotiations between prosecution and defense over redacting names of Assistant U.S. Attorneys (AUSAs), accusers (victims), and third parties from public court filings.
The defense indicated it had no objection to removing redactions for accusers and a specific individual (name redacted in text), but redacted AUSA names as a courtesy.
Multiple reply briefs (1, 3, 5, 6, 10) and their exhibits were under discussion, with disagreements on whether they should be filed publicly, under seal, or with specific redactions.
The government's position was that redactions were necessary to protect the privacy interests of victims and third parties, as designated under a Protective Order.
The correspondence was prompted by court orders (Dkt. 203, 207) requiring the parties to confer and propose redactions for undocketed reply briefs.
